subject: AI & Agents
title: Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov
description: A micro-lesson that makes Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov usable.

hook.text: May 11, 1997. The world chess champion stares at the board, stunned. A machine just beat him.

buildup.text: IBM's Deep Blue evaluated 200 million positions per second using brute-force search.

discovery.text: It combined raw computation with hand-tuned chess knowledge from grandmasters.

twist.text: Kasparov accused IBM of cheating. IBM refused a rematch and dismantled Deep Blue.

climax.text: The world realized machines could conquer games once thought to require human genius.

punchline.text: The king fell to a calculator with great taste in moves.

quiz.question: How did Deep Blue play chess?
options: Brute-force search evaluating millions of positions per second
Neural networks trained on chess games
